articles.headline: For Trump, Book Raises Familiar Questions of Loyalty and Candor
articles.snippet: Every president is confronted by unflattering portrayals by former aides who leave and tell their stories, but usually not so early in an administration.
articles.abstract: Every president is confronted by unflattering portrayals by former aides who leave and tell their stories, but usually not so early in an administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In President George W. Bush’s last year in office, his former press secretary, Scott McClellan, wrote a tell-all book concluding that the Iraq war was a “serious strategic blunder” based on the “ambition, certitude and self-deceit” of a White House that was not fully honest with the American people.

articles.headline: Republican Senators Raise Possible Charges Against Author of Trump Dossier
articles.snippet: The first congressional criminal referral in connection with Russian meddling targeted a former British spy, not anyone accused of conspiracy.
articles.abstract: The first congressional criminal referral in connection with Russian meddling targeted a former British spy, not anyone accused of conspiracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — More than a year after Republican leaders promised to investigate Russian interference in the presidential election, two influential Republicans on Friday made the first known congressional criminal referral in connection with the meddling — against one of the people who sought to expose it.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: As a 2-State Solution Loses Steam, a 1-State Plan Gains Traction
articles.snippet: Some Israeli and Palestinian leaders are now pressing for a single state, but their views of what that state would look like are mutually exclusive.
articles.abstract: Some Israeli and Palestinian leaders are now pressing for a single state, but their views of what that state would look like are mutually exclusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli right, emboldened by President Trump’s recognition of Jerusalem as Israel’s capital, is not the only faction arguing for a single state between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea.

articles.headline: From Mexico to the U.S., a Nafta Tale of Two Truckers
articles.snippet: Restricted from operating in the United States, most Mexican drivers must hand off their cargo. The Trump administration wants even tighter controls.
articles.abstract: Restricted from operating in the United States, most Mexican drivers must hand off their cargo. The Trump administration wants even tighter controls.
articles.lead_paragraph: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico — Raúl García Miranda wants Carlos Flores’s job. Mr. Flores doesn’t think he deserves it.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and George Etheredge

articles.headline: A Swiss Banker Helped Americans Dodge Taxes. Was It a Crime?
articles.snippet: Stefan Buck created bank accounts for dozens of Americans hiding money from tax collectors. The U.S. tried to hold him personally accountable.
articles.abstract: Stefan Buck created bank accounts for dozens of Americans hiding money from tax collectors. The U.S. tried to hold him personally accountable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Diane Butrus, a business executive from St. Louis, wandered the streets of Zurich, looking for a bank that would help her keep $1.5 million hidden from America tax collectors.

articles.headline: Trump, Defending His Mental Fitness, Says He’s a ‘Very Stable Genius’
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump, seeming to respond to revelations in a new book, issued an extraordinary defense of his fitness for office.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump, seeming to respond to revelations in a new book, issued an extraordinary defense of his fitness for office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, whose sometimes erratic behavior in office has generated an unprecedented debate about his mental health, declared on Saturday that he was perfectly sane and accused his critics of raising questions to score political points.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Tapes Reveal Egyptian Leaders’ Tacit Acceptance of Jerusalem Move
articles.snippet: While Egypt denounced President Trump’s decision, an Egyptian intelligence officer coached talk show hosts to persuade their listeners to accept it.
articles.abstract: While Egypt denounced President Trump’s decision, an Egyptian intelligence officer coached talk show hosts to persuade their listeners to accept it.
articles.lead_paragraph: As President Trump moved last month to recognize Jerusalem as the capital of Israel, an Egyptian intelligence officer quietly placed phone calls to the hosts of several influential talk shows in Egypt.

articles.headline: How U.S. Intelligence Agencies Underestimated North Korea
articles.snippet: For decades, they warned the North was making progress on a missile that could reach the United States. But the last breakthroughs happened faster than they expected.
articles.abstract: For decades, they warned the North was making progress on a missile that could reach the United States. But the last breakthroughs happened faster than they expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At the start of Donald Trump’s presidency, American intelligence agencies told the new administration that while North Korea had built the bomb, there was still ample time — upward of four years — to slow or stop its development of a missile capable of hitting an American city with a nuclear warhead.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: India’s Economic Woes Are Piercing Modi’s Aura of Invulnerability
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s policies are being criticized as India’s hot economy cools. But with society so polarized, his Hindu base still appears solid.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s policies are being criticized as India’s hot economy cools. But with society so polarized, his Hindu base still appears solid.
articles.lead_paragraph: SURAT, India — The immense popularity of Narendra Modi, India’s most dynamic prime minister in decades, has always rested on two legs: Hindu nationalism and his tantalizing promises to build on the country’s go-go economy.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: In Clash Between California and Trump, It’s One America Versus Another
articles.snippet: The growing divide between California and President Trump erupted this week, over marijuana, immigration, taxes and the environment.
articles.abstract: The growing divide between California and President Trump erupted this week, over marijuana, immigration, taxes and the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When drivers entered California recently from the borders with Arizona and Nevada, they were greeted with  signs welcoming them to an “official sanctuary state” that is home to “felons” and “illegals.” It was a prank, but the message was clear: By entering California, they might as well have been entering foreign territory.

articles.headline: Trump’s Twitter Threats Put American Credibility on the Line
articles.snippet: Nearly a year after the president took office, the world is still figuring out whether to take his fiery words as policy pronouncements, or to simply ignore them.
articles.abstract: Nearly a year after the president took office, the world is still figuring out whether to take his fiery words as policy pronouncements, or to simply ignore them.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Since the first of the year, President Trump has attacked a variety of countries in Twitter posts, urging protesters to overthrow the Iranian government, threatening to blow up North Korea and calling for cuts in aid to the Palestinians. In bluster and tone, he has begun 2018 where he left off.

articles.headline: Kushner’s Financial Ties to Israel Deepen Even With Mideast Diplomatic Role
articles.snippet: An Israeli insurance company’s previously undisclosed $30 million investment in Jared Kushner’s family company could fuel the perception of conflicts of interest.
articles.abstract: An Israeli insurance company’s previously undisclosed $30 million investment in Jared Kushner’s family company could fuel the perception of conflicts of interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last May, Jared Kushner accompanied President Trump, his father-in-law, on the pair’s first diplomatic trip to Israel, part of Mr. Kushner’s White House assignment to achieve peace in the Middle East.

articles.headline: Bannon Tries Backing Away From Explosive Comments
articles.snippet: Stephen K. Bannon, who is quoted in a new book calling Donald Trump Jr.’s meeting with Russians in 2016 “treasonous,” said that Mr. Trump was “both a patriot and a good man.”
articles.abstract: Stephen K. Bannon, who is quoted in a new book calling Donald Trump Jr.’s meeting with Russians in 2016 “treasonous,” said that Mr. Trump was “both a patriot and a good man.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s supporters moved aggressively on Sunday to counter revelations in a new book that some of his closest aides believe he is unstable and ill equipped for office, an assault that prompted the source of some of the most damning accusations, Stephen K. Bannon, to issue a striking mea culpa.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Michael Tackett

articles.headline: Losing Faith in the State, Some Mexican Towns Quietly Break Away
articles.snippet: With government often more the problem than the solution, communities are taking matters into their own hands. But gains against crime can carry a cost.
articles.abstract: With government often more the problem than the solution, communities are taking matters into their own hands. But gains against crime can carry a cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: TANCÍTARO, Mexico — The road to this agricultural town winds through the slums and cartel-controlled territory of Michoacán, ground zero for Mexico’s drug war, before arriving at a sight so strange it can seem like a mirage.
articles.byline: By Max Fisher, Amanda Taub and Dalia Martínez

articles.headline: Can Sweatcoin, a Hot Fitness App, Keep You Off the Couch?
articles.snippet: Sweatcoin has been a popular download for months by offering a twist to fitness tracking. Users gain “sweatcoins” that can be used to buy products.
articles.abstract: Sweatcoin has been a popular download for months by offering a twist to fitness tracking. Users gain “sweatcoins” that can be used to buy products.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent evening with a windchill of 11 degrees, I made myself put down a book I had been enjoying and go out on the streets of New York instead.

articles.headline: India Clings to Cash, Even as Tech Firms Push Digital Money
articles.snippet: India’s Paytm and global heavyweights like Google are moving aggressively to persuade reluctant Indians to give up their rupee notes.
articles.abstract: India’s Paytm and global heavyweights like Google are moving aggressively to persuade reluctant Indians to give up their rupee notes.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALIGARH, India — Signs and banners for Paytm, India’s biggest digital payments service, festoon Pooran Singh’s cellphone shop, where people drop in all day to add data or talk time to their prepaid phones.
articles.byline: By Vindu Goel and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: Bannon Needs Breitbart. Does Breitbart Need Bannon?
articles.snippet: After he was quoted speaking critically of Donald Trump Jr., the former White House strategist appears to be trying to stay at the right-wing news site.
articles.abstract: After he was quoted speaking critically of Donald Trump Jr., the former White House strategist appears to be trying to stay at the right-wing news site.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks after Stephen K. Bannon’s ouster from the Trump White House last August, his flagship organization Breitbart News verged, at times, on a Bannon vanity project.

articles.headline: Condé Nast Chooses a Digital-First Editor to Run Glamour
articles.snippet: Samantha Barry, a producer at CNN Worldwide from Cork, Ireland, is set to become the eighth editor of the women’s magazine, succeeding Cindi Leive.
articles.abstract: Samantha Barry, a producer at CNN Worldwide from Cork, Ireland, is set to become the eighth editor of the women’s magazine, succeeding Cindi Leive.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Samantha Barry was growing up in Ireland, she and her family would gather around the television to watch the 6 o’clock news. They also told stories around the dinner table and read a number of newspapers and magazines, including Vogue and old issues of Time.

articles.headline: Trump Administration Says That Nearly 200,000 Salvadorans Must Leave
articles.snippet: The administration decided that Salvadorans no longer qualified for temporary protection from deportation that had been granted after two devastating earthquakes in 2001.
articles.abstract: The administration decided that Salvadorans no longer qualified for temporary protection from deportation that had been granted after two devastating earthquakes in 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Nearly 200,000 people from El Salvador who have been allowed to live in the United States for more than a decade must leave the country, government officials announced Monday. It is the Trump administration’s latest reversal of years of immigration policies and one of the most consequential to date.
